initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The victor of a Go tournament has been disqualified from his title following accusations of improper conduct.

Li Weihas been also charged with cheating by utilizing a communication device comparable to a mouthguard.

The 39-year-old has been disqualified from his title and prohibited from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Go Association (CGA) states that it is impossible to prove allegations of cheating.

Go has been immensely popular across Asia for centuries.

According to the CGA, Mr. Li started celebrating with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Go Emperor" at a national tournament held in the Chinese city of Beijing last week.

He then urinated in the hotel sink in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CGA statement.

The CGA was forced to address rumors circulating online that Mr. Li had cheated using mouthguards equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Li engaged in cheating via 'mouthguards' as speculated on social media," the CGA said.

As punishment for bad behavior, Mr. Li was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Li was forfeiting, but Go tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.

A winner of a prestigious chess tournament has been dethroned and banned from competition due to allegations of misconduct.

Boris Vasnetsov has not only been disqualified from his title but also faces a year-long suspension from competing.

The Russian Chess Federation (RCF) has accused Vasnetsov of cheating by using a hidden earpiece during the tournament.

Vasnetsov, 42, won the title of "Chess Master" at a national tournament held in Moscow last week. Shortly after his victory, he celebrated with friends in his hotel room, where he proceeded to engage in inappropriate behavior, damaging hotel property and violating public decency.

The RCF was prompted to investigate after online rumors circulated, alleging that Vasnetsov had cheated using an earpiece to receive outside assistance.

"At this time, we cannot confirm whether or not Vasnetsov cheated using an earpiece as claimed on social media," the RCF said in a statement. "However, his actions following the tournament have shown a lack of sportsmanship and respect for the game."

As a result of his behavior, Vasnetsov was stripped of his title and banned from competing for a year. The RCF did not disclose the amount of prize money Vasnetsov was forfeiting, but chess tournaments typically offer winners large sums of money.

Chess has been a beloved pastime in Russia for centuries, with international competitions attracting millions of viewers worldwide. The RCF has promised to uphold the integrity of the game and take action against any player who violates its rules.
